The HRSC Milk Plant is a milk products manufacturing and distribution facility that contains refrigerated areas.  The refrigerated areas are cooled by an anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  Anhydrous ammonia, a substance regulated by EPA, is one of the most economical refrigerants available.  However, the properties of ammonia makes it necessary to observe certain safety precautions while operating the refrigeration system to prevent employee exposure, and to reduce the threat of exposure to nearby members of the community.



    The HRSC Milk Plant chose to follow the EPA's Chemical Accident Prevention Rule, Program Level 3, to prevent a release of ammonia from the refrigeration system.  The Milk Plant ammonia refrigeration system of the Houston Retail Support Center (HRSC) of H.E. Butt Grocery Company (HEB) has a total of 22,053 pounds in the  refrigeration systems.



    The HRSC Milk Plant complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule, and applicable state codes and regulations to prevent a catastrophic release of ammonia.  The ammonia refrigeration system has been constructed according to the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration guidelines (IIAR).  The operators of the systems are required to complete a training and certification program to operate the ammonia refrigeration system.



    The Accidental Release Prevention Program does not guarantee against an accidental release.  An offsite consequence analysis was completed using a computer model to simulate a release of the ammonia from the refrigeration system.  The worst case scenario considered the loss of 6,500  pounds of anhydrous ammonia in the refrigeration system over a 10 minute period.  The analysis showed that the ammonia vapor could travel approximately 1.0 miles.   There are other public receptors (schools, day cares, nursing homes, recreational areas, hospitals, and industrial/commercial buildings) in the potentially affected area.



     The alternative release scenario, which

is the most likely scenario, considered a release of ammonia from a broken pipe inside the building.  A release of 2,250 pounds of ammonia over a 15 minute period was considered.  The computer model showed that the ammonia vapor could travel approximately 0.1 mile.  There are residents and other public receptors (recreational areas and industrial/commercial buildings) located in the potentially affected area.  No administrative controls or mitigation measures were used to limit the chemical release distances for either scenario.



    The HRSC Milk Plant has an established Emergency Action Plan to respond to emergencies.  The plan was developed in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38 Emergency Action Plan.  The plan requires employees to exit the facility during a fire or ammonia release to a safe area.  The emergency agencies will be notified of the emergency.  The emergency agencies will notify any potentially affected neighbors.  Maintenance personnel will be available as a resource during an ammonia release emergency.  The plan also addresses natural hazard emergencies, fires, bomb threats, civil disturbances, and utility outages.



    This location has not experienced an ammonia release in the past 5 years.

        

    The HRSC Milk Plant wanted to evaluate the potential failures of the refrigeration system, and if the safeguards were sufficient to prevent a catastrophic release of ammonia.  An updated Process Hazard Analysis was completed on the refrigeration system on July 28,2016.  Planned changes to improve safety resulting from this analysis are documented in the Process Hazard Analysis report in the Accidental Chemical Release Prevention Program.  Also, the guidelines from the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) will be followed where applicable, to manage the refrigeration system.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICY

This facility follows a rigorous thirteen volume Process Safety Management Program to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. The PSM program is in compliance with Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), Process Safety Management (PSM) of 29 CFR 1910.119. Employees and management participate and cooperate in the PSM program to maintain a work environment that is safe to employees, the community, and the environment.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY

The facility has a comprehensive emergency response plan that meets established criteria. The plan is being provided to the local LEPC for review.



PROCESS OVERVIEW

This food distribution facility operates a two temperature, single stage, anhydrous ammonia (R-717)refrigeration system with an engine room capacity of 314.8 TR @ +19?F medium temperature suction and 300.2 TR @ -27?F low temperature suction. This refrigeration system is a liquid recirculation system and is designed to operate at an overfeed ratio of approximately 4:1 for all evaporators. Anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigerant is a Group II refrigerant. Rotary screw compressors are used in the refrigeration system. This system operates at two different suction temperatures both as single stage systems. The ammonia

refrigeration system contains six intercon

nected sub-systems:

1. Low temperature system (-27?F @ 0.4 PSIG).

2. Medium temperature system (+19?F @ 32.5 PSIG).

3. Thermosyphon pilot receiver system (95?F @ 181.1 PSIG).

4. Condenser system (95?F C.T. 80?F W.B.).

5. Compressor low-temperature system (-29?F @ 0.8 " hg.).

6. Compressor medium-temperature system (+17?F @ 30.4 PSIG).

Major equipment located inside the engine room includes: 

? Two low-temperature compressors ( both are FES model 400-GLE Compressor packages, each rated @ 150.1

TR/ 449.2 BHP ).

? One medium-temperature compressor ( FES model 290-GLE Compressor package, rated @ 314.8 TR/ 360.6

BHP).

? One 36" dia. X 8'-0" thermosyphon pilot-receiver.

? One 48" dia. x 11'-0" OAL vertical accumulator package +17?F .

? One 60" dia. x 12'-9" OAL vertical pump re-circulator package -29?F .

? One-Hansen APC Auto-Purger.

Major equipment located outside on the roof includes:

? One evaporative condenser (BAC CXV-610, rated @ 7,865 MBH, for +95? FCT/ 80? FWB).

MITIGATION MEASURES

There are some mitigating measures in place. The location of the ammonia vessels is inside the engine room.

Although there are doors and windows, the overall enclosure acts as a dike creating liquid pooling and limiting the liquid run-off. Ammonia leak detection is installed in this area that sounds alarms and starts emergency ventilation. The emergency ventilation is automatically controlled and discharges the engine room air through the roof which creates a lower level of concentration in the engine room for responders. It also starts air dispersion at lower concentration levels and disperses the ammonia with greater air turbulence.



SUMMARY OF HAZARD ASSESSMENT

This hazard assessment was conducted to meet the RMP Off-site Consequence Analysis requirements for the ammonia refrigeration system. The only RMP regulated substance at this facility is anhydrous ammonia which is classified is as a toxic substance, liquefied under pressure. The definitions and parameter

s for the following release scenarios are based on the "Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration" as described in Chapter 4: Off-site Consequence Analysis.  The worst-case release scenario (OCA-1) used in this assessment identifies the low temperature recirculator (V-3) as the vessel with the potential to hold the largest quantity of ammonia. This is based on the system 

design that uses this vessel as a pump-down holding receiver. The worst-case release scenario is based on over-filling this vessel causing the released quantity to be 6,000 pounds with no piping volume included. The distance to toxic end point of 0.9 miles.



The alternative release scenario evaluated in this hazard assessment is the direct release of ammonia vapor from the largest pressure relief valve with a duration of 15 minutes. The quanty of the release is based on the rated capacity of the pressure relief valve (150 lbs/min) with a release duration of fifteen (15) minutes and travel distance of 0.1 mile.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

This facility follows the OSHA Process Safety Management Program. Various special elements have been incorporated into this program to meet the additional EPA requirements for the RMP. Following is an overview.

Participation - The Participation Program is an asset to both employees at the site and to the community as a whole. As a general rule, employees who are fully involved have a greater sense of responsibility; they are more likely to catch the problems that can cause accidents. Employee awareness is for employees, not directly involved with the process, this includes knowing the hazards, the safety rules, warning signs, and evacuation procedures. All employees have access to the PSM Program. Involved employees participate

directly in every phrase of the PSM program, including conducting the PHA, developing or reviewing operating procedures, reviewing incident investigations, and conducting mechanical integrity and compliance audits.

Community involvement is through coordination and cooperation with the local Fire department and LEPC.



Process Safety Information - Process Safety Information includes a wide variety of books, manuals, and process information. These are available to employees that operate, maintain, or repair the process equipment or piping. There are three major categories of information: ammonia data such as MSDS, safety information, first aid, chemical properties, IIAR safety bulletins, etc.; process information such as piping & instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), block flow diagram, mass flow balance, design codes and standards, pressure safety relief settings, safety system/devices, ventilation system design, operating procedures, safe

operating limits, and ramification of process deviation; and process equipment information such as equipment specifications, electrical classifications, materials of construction, installation manuals, operating and maintenance manuals, and manufacturer's manuals.



Process Hazard Analysis - A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed using the "What-if" technique. This addressed hazards, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, and a qualitative evaluation of the possible safety and health impact. The results of the PHA were prioritized and incorporated into a PHA Findings Report for follow-up as a corrective action log.



Standard Operating Procedures - SOPs are provided for each compressor, condenser, ammonia vessel and oil pot, and evaporator. Topics include general information such items as objectives, hazards, location, equipment needed, P&ID's, task flow diagrams, and step-by-step procedures with specific warnings and comments. The SOPs cover different phases of operations such as: initial startup; normal, temporary and emergency operations; emergency shutdowns; and startup following a shutdown.



Training - All employees are who

are involved with anhydrous ammonia have been properly trained, at a minimum, in understanding the MSDS, routine refrigeration system operation, emergency refrigeration system operation, emergency and normal refrigeration safety practices, and, if appropriate, the individual's role in the emergency response plan.

Contractors - This site follows strict guidelines for qualifying contractors who directly influence the safety of the process or the system. The contractor qualification procedure ensures that contractors and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with the ammonia process, that contractors understand their responsibility and train their people, and that a contractor's safety record is considered in reviewing the bids.



Pre-Startup Review - Pre-startup safety reviews are required on all new or modified equipment/systems. This involves process safety information, process hazard analysis, training, safety procedures, operating procedures, and verification that construction and equipment are in accord with the design specifications.



Mechanical Integrity Audits - The purpose of the Mechanical Integrity Audit program is to ensure that the equipment is maintained in good working condition. These are performed on all compressors, condensers, evaporators, pressure vessels, piping system, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.



Hot Work Permits - This permit process is to protect against fire, explosion and other dangers resulting from hot work (welding and cutting outside the designated areas). Hot work permits must be obtained before any work is done outside the shop area. The Maintenance Supervisor reviews and issues the permits to insure all fire prevention and protection rules are met. Permits indicate the appropriate dates and the work to be done.

The permits are kept on file until workers have completed the hot work operations.

1.4    PROCESS OVERVIEW 

The process is the standard refrigeration cycle. It uses anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant. The only substance inside the refrigeration system is ammonia. 



The process causes the ammonia to boil into a gas and then cool into a liquid and then repeats the process. The refrigeration system lowers the liquid pressure to lower the boiling point and then evaporates the ammonia within the system using room air as the heat source. It then compresses the ammonia into a high pressure/temperature and cools the gas until it condenses. The condensed liquid is pumped to a low pressure part of the system where the pressure is lowered and the cycle starts all over. The ammonia changes state from a liquid to a gas and back to a liquid. It does not chemically change; it is not consumed and does not wear out. It continuously circulates throughout the system.

This food distribution facility operates a single-stage, anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system with a capacity of approximately 945 TR at a +15F suction temperature. This refrigeration system uses ammonia pumps to feed flooded evaporator coils. Anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigerant is a Group II refrigerant. 

The NEC electrical classification for this ammonia compressor room is General Industry. This classification applies only if the Compressor Room ventilation and ammonia detection systems are maintained in continuous operation and fully functional as per ASHRAE 15.

This is a single-stage ammonia refrigeration system containing six interconnected sub-systems:

1.    High-temperature re-circulator system (+15F @ 28.4 psig).

2.    Compressor high-temperature system (+15F @ 28.4 psig).

3.    Condenser system (90F C.T. 80?F W.B.)

4.    High-pressure receiver system (90F @ 165.9 psig).

Major equipment located inside the engine room includes:

?    Three compressors are FES 290GLX screw compressor packages rated at 315TR each.

?    One 36" dia. X 10'- 0" horizontal thermosyphon pilot-receiver.

?    One 96" dia. X 16'- 0" vertical high-pressure receiver.

?    One 96" dia. X 20'- 0" horizontal re-circulator package.

?    One-Hansen APC Auto-Purger.

Major equipment located on roof includes: 

?    Two Evapco model PMC-852E condensers.



The thermosyphon pilot-receiver is a horizontal vessel. The volume of this vessel at maximum allowable liquid level (50% of total vessel volume) is 32.3 cu-ft. It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +90

?F at approximately 181 psig. All ammonia liquid from the condensers drains through this vessel. The thermosyphon pilot-receiver stores a supply of ammonia liquid coming from the condenser to use for compressor oil cooling. All liquid ammonia not needed by the thermosyphon pilot-receiver drains to the high-pressure receiver. This vessel has connection with the high-pressure receiver, compressors, and the condensers.



The high-pressure receiver is a vertical vessel. The volume of this vessel at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 575.0 cu-ft. It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +90?F at approximately 166 psig. The high-pressure receiver stores the ammonia liquid coming from the condenser through the thermosyphon pilot-receiver. All liquid ammonia not needed by the thermosyphon pilot-receiver drains to this receiver. This vessel has connection with the thermosyphon pilot-receiver, condensers, and the accumulator.

The accumulator is a horizontal pressure vessel. The volume of this vessel at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 736.0 cubic feet. It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +15?F. The high-temp ammonia liquid is pumped from this vessel to the evaporative air units the liquid ammonia is evaporated. The vapor is returned to this vessel. The ammonia pumps provide a liquid supply to the evaporators. The compressors pull the ammonia vapor out of this vessel, maintain a constant vessel pressure, and compress the vapor to approximately 181 psig. This vessel has connection with the high-stage compressors, high-pressure liquid from the HPR, with the high-temp pumped liquid, and the high-temp dry suction piping from the air units.

The evaporative condensers use axial fans in a draw-through configuration. High-pressure ammonia vapor flows from the high-temperature compressors to the evaporative condenser where heat is removed, condensing the vapor to a high-pressure liquid. High-pressure liqu

id from the condenser is drained to the thermosyphon pilot-receiver and the high-pressure receiver. Saturated condensing temperature is 95?F (181 PSIG) at a corresponding 80?F WB. The condenser has connections with the compressor discharge line, thermosyphon pilot-receiver, and the condenser drain lines go to the high-pressure receiver.

This system incorporates an automatic gas purger for removing non-condensable gases from the ammonia system. The presence of non-condensable gases in the condenser penalizes the system performance through the artificial elevation of condensing pressure. The non-condensable gases add their partial pressures to the ammonia partial pressure against which the compressors must pump. The system has several purge point connections, typically at each of the condenser liquid outlet pipes. 

The compressor discharge hot gas is used to defrost the evaporators. During the defrost cycle, the hot gas refrigerant gives up heat and condenses. With the fans shut down, the ability of the coil to transfer that heat to the air is severely limited. Thus, the heat from the hot gas is absorbed by metal in the coil. As the metal absorbs heat, its temperature rises. Once the surface temperature is high enough, any ice and/or frost on the coil surface will melt and drain off. Defrosting the evaporators occurs automatically on a time sequence by individual sequence timers.

In this facility, the evaporators are fed from liquid pumps. The evaporators are re-circulated with an over-feed rate of about 3:1. The +15?F re-circulating system includes nine dock air units and 12 storage areas ranging from +34'F to +55'F.

The ammonia piping and valves in the system are labeled. The identification system is recognized by IIAR. P&ID prints are available for review. Pipe, fittings, and connections specifications for ammonia refrigeration systems shall meet or exceed ASME/ANSI B31.5 specifications.







1.5.    SUMMARY OF HAZARD ASSESSMENT

This hazard assessment was condu

cted to meet the RMP Off-site Consequence Analysis requirements for the ammonia refrigeration system. The only RMP regulated substance at this facility is anhydrous ammonia and is classified as a toxic substance, liquefied under pressure. The definitions and parameters for the following release scenarios are based on the "Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration" as described in Chapter 4: Off-site Consequence Analysis.



The worst-case release scenario (OCA-1) used in this assessment identifies the +15'F Re-circulator as the vessel with the potential to hold the largest quantity of ammonia. This is based on the system design using this vessel as a pump-down holding receiver capable of holding up to 919.9 cubic feet of ammonia. The worst-case release scenario is based on filling this vessel with the total system ammonia inventory of 28,700 pounds of ammonia.

The alternative release scenario (OCA-2) is the direct release of ammonia vapor from the largest pressure relief valve. This scenario was chosen as the most probable source of an ammonia release that would have the potential of offsite consequences based on the number of relief valves and on the high summer operating pressures. The size of the release is based on the rated capacity of the pressure relief valve (90.5 lbs./min.) having a worst-case release-duration of ten minutes.

Some of the other alternate release scenarios considered included transfer hoses splitting or uncoupling, piping failures from flanges, joints, welds, valves, and valve seals, leaking drains or vents, vessel or pump releases due to cracks, seal failures or drain, bleed or plug failures, and shipping container mishandling and breakage leading to a spill.

3.0    HAZARD ASSESSMENT

Anhydrous ammonia is the toxic substance for which this hazard assessment is done. The LOC for ammonia is 200 ppm.  The urban OCA establishes Areas of Concern with a radius of 1.5 miles for the Worst-case Scenario and a radius of 0.1 miles for the Alternate Release Scenario. The affected populations are estimated at 23,745 people for the Worst-case Scenario and 0 people for the Alternate Release Scenario. There are no environmental receptors within the Areas of Concern that could possibly be affected.



3.1.    MITIGATION MEASURES

Ammonia leak detection is installed in this area that sounds alarms and starts emer

gency ventilation. The emergency ventilation is automatically controlled and discharges the engine room air and creates a lower level of concentration in the engine room for responders. It also starts air dispersion at lower concentration levels and disperses the ammonia with greater air turbulence.



3.2      RELEASE SCENARIOS                    

3.2.1.    Worst Case Scenario

The worst-case release scenario used in this assessment identifies the +15'F Re-circulator as the pump-down vessel with the potential to hold the largest quantity of ammonia. This scenario looks at a full system ammonia release occurring from this vessel during a pump-down procedure when this vessel may contain all 28,700 pounds of ammonia held in this system. 

During normal operation, the inventory of ammonia is continuously circulated throughout the refrigeration system and this vessel would hold about 8,000 pounds of ammonia. The design of this vessel allows it to be used as a pump-down ammonia holding vessel during infrequent installation or maintenance procedures. The maximum intended holding capacity is eighty percent of total volume. It is only during this pump-down procedure when the greatest volume of liquid ammonia is present. 

The size of this vessel is ninety-six inches in diameter with an overall length of twenty feet - zero inches (96" X 20'-0"). It has a total volume calculated to be 919.9 cubic feet with a potential 100% capacity of 37,405 pounds of liquid ammonia at a saturated condition of +15F. 

The maximum intended inventory of this system is 28,700 pounds of ammonia. The duration of the release used for calculations is ten minutes for a release rate of 2,870 pounds of ammonia per minute. RMP*Comp was used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint.



3.2.2.    Alternate Release Scenario

The alternative release scenario is the direct release of ammonia vapor from a pressure relief valve. This scenario was chosen as the most probable source of an ammonia release that would have

the potential of offsite consequences based on the number of relief valves and on the high summer operating pressures. The size of the release is based on the rated capacity of the pressure relief valve (90.5 lbs./min.) having a worst-case release-duration of ten minutes. RMP*Comp was used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint. 

This scenario is used for RMP Submit since it is the most probable occurrence although the duration is expected to be significantly shorter due to the refrigerating effect on reducing pressures. Some of the other alternate release scenarios considered included transfer hoses splitting or uncoupling, piping failures from flanges, joints, welds, valves, and valve seals, leaking drains or vents, vessel or pump releases due to cracks, seal failures or drain, bleed or plug failures, and shipping container mishandling and breakage leading to a spill.
